poem:
**Economy in February**

Beyond the cautious gaze of city forecasters,  
winter's burrowed breath,  
a dash of spring—0.5%—  
peeks shyly over  
the ledger's edge.   
Rachel, you glean a brief reprieve  
as distant tariffs loom,  
unscripted gusts—  
brief feathers in flight—  
before the heavy sky weighs down  
once more.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "UK economy far exceeds forecasts to grow 0.5% in boost to Rachel Reeves The UK economy unexpectedly expanded by 0.5% in February, figures show, in a boost for the chancellor, Rachel Reeves, before an expected downturn sparked by Donald Trump’s tariff war. The increase in gross domestic product in February was five times larger than the 0.1% that a poll of City economists had forecast, while January’s figure of a modest fall of 0.1% was". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
